message: I would like to wish everyone a very happy New Year. Let's work to make 2017 a great year for all Americans!
I'm honored to serve the people of Ohio's 16th District yet again. Thank you for the opportunity to represent you in Washington!

Outgoing presidential administrations frequently rush to enact high-cost and politically-driven rules and regulations – often called “midnight rules” – during their last days and months in office to entrench their agenda. This Administration is no different. Yesterday, I voted for the Midnight Rules Relief Act to stop the Administration’s latest rules, which avoid transparency and circumvent the will of millions of voters who demanded change.   We must roll back harmful regulations like the Stream Protection Rule, which will destroy Ohio’s coal industry and thousands of good-paying jobs with it. The current administration must honor the direction our country chose for itself in the election.

Yesterday, I voted to stand with one of our truest allies. The House passed H.Res. 11, a resolution I cosponsored that condemns the UN’s anti-Israel Resolution 2334. As Israel is one of the only democracies in the Middle East, we must stand up for what is right and reject the UN’s biased views and pronouncements on one of our closest friends. The United States must not let the U.N. take any further actions against Israel at the Paris Conference on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict scheduled for January 15th.  Looking to the future, it is my hope that the Trump Administration and subsequent administrations recognize and commit themselves to the bond we share with Israel and move to veto any U.N. resolution inserting itself into the peace process. A durable and sustainable peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians will come only through direct bilateral negotiations between the parties.  #StandWithIsrael

You are isolated, you can’t join in conversations, you appear stupid, meetings and church are difficult, and for me being a teacher it was especially difficult. Please know I will never forget what the Congressman has done to help this WWII Veteran have a better and happier life for the remaining time left for me.”   If you know of anyone having difficulties with a federal agency such as the VA, please direct them to my offices. While I cannot always guarantee a favorable outcome, I am pleased to help my constituents on these matters.

Today I was proud to join my colleagues in passing the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act.   Currently, the Hyde Amendment prohibits taxpayer funding to pay for abortions, but it only applies to select government agencies and must be renewed on an annual basis. This legislation does three important things. First, it makes the Hyde Amendment and other abortion funding prohibitions permanent and government-wide except in the case of incest, rape, or if the life of the mother is in danger. Second, it ensures the Affordable Care Act conforms to the provisions of the Hyde Amendment.  And finally, until a new plan year begins, the bill requires each Obamacare health insurance plan to provide full transparency on the extent to which it uses taxpayer funds for abortion.   According to two recent studies by the Lozier Institute and the Knights of Columbus, two million Americans are alive today due to the Hyde Amendment and more than 60% of Americans believe that tax dollars should not fund abortions, including 4 in 10 Clinton voters. Life is a precious gift and I look forward to working this Congress to pass further pro-life initiatives.

Above all else, the top priority of the federal government is to keep our nation safe for all Americans, and I have unequivocally supported full enforcement of our immigrant laws as well as enhanced vetting of individuals seeking to visit the United States from nations identified with terrorist activity, regardless of their ethnicity or religion.  As a nation of immigrants, founded on the bedrock principle of religious freedom, we must never impose religious tests of any kind on anyone, and it’s clear that President Trump’s Executive Order has not imposed one.   While I strongly encourage the Administration to examine more closely whether it is effectual and necessary to subject green card holders from these nations to this temporary order, I fully support our government's renewed commitment to keeping Americans of all faiths safe and free across our homeland.

Today, I urged my colleagues to disapprove the Social Security Administration’s rule to submit the names of millions of disability beneficiaries to the National Instant Background Check System. This rule does not allow for any meaningful due process protections and is so broadly written it inaccurately treats any individual with a mental health issue as violent and a danger to public safety.  Numerous mental health advocacy organizations including the National Alliance on Mental Illness and the National Council on Disability along with the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) have joined me in opposing this rule.

Today, my staff received a letter from a constituent of mine thanking them for helping her obtain Hardship Mail Delivery Service. A person can receive such service if the United States Postal Service determines an illness or handicap  would present a physical challenge for an individual to retrieve mail.  After initially being denied an accommodation, she reached out to my office, and we were more than happy to help her with her request. She wrote to us to say her new mailbox by her door was "one of the best Christmas presents ever."  If you know of anyone having difficulties with a federal agency or department, please direct them to my offices. While I cannot always guarantee a favorable outcome, I am pleased to help my constituents on these matters.

As a supporter of the full enforcement of our immigration laws and the thorough vetting of those who seek to enter our country, I am disappointed in tonight’s ruling. The top priority of the federal government is to keep our nation safe for all Americans, and federal immigration law gives the President broad power to suspend entry of certain individuals into the United States if they are deemed detrimental to our interests and national security. I am optimistic that the Supreme Court will review this ruling and put the Constitution and American people ahead of politics.

Neil Gorsuch is truly the perfect successor to Justice Scalia. He has a brilliant legal mind and a sterling judicial record. It is no wonder, then, that his nomination has drawn support from both liberal and conservative circles.

On this day in 1945, the 5-week American invasion of the island of Iwo Jima began. Joe Rosenthal’s Associated Press photo of the US Marines on Mt. Suribachi raising the American flag has become iconic as not just a symbol for that individual battle, but of the whole Pacific Theater. The sacrifices made there can never be repaid and will never be forgotten.

Happy Birthday to the over 100,000-strong US Navy Reserve. Answering the call of your country in every engagement since World War I, you truly are "Ready Now, Anytime, Anywhere." Thank you for your service to our country.

A Congressional charter in 1919 established the American Legion as a "Patriotic Veterans Organization." Since their first caucus meeting on this date in 1919 up until now, 98 years later, they have served Veterans and their families tirelessly. The American Legion now has over 2.4 million members and 14,000 posts worldwide. Legionnaires, your service to our Veterans is indispensable.

Today, on the anniversary of the first ever awarding of the Medal of Honor, we recognize all those who have earned the highest military honor awarded by the United States. At the Ohio Veterans Memorial Park in Clinton stands the Medal of Honor Memorial where I have had the honor of meeting several Medal of Honor recipients. Their willingness to go above and beyond in their service to our country should be an example to all of us every day.

Today on Vietnam Veterans’ Day, we recognize those who served during the Vietnam War and who may not have received the welcome home and thanks they deserved for answering the call of their nation. To them today we say: “Thank you and welcome home.”

When a service member makes the ultimate sacrifice for their country it is more than one life that is affected.  Gold Star Wives Day seeks to recognize those resilient and courageous women who have also sacrificed for our nation and carry on the memories of their fallen spouses.

Happy Birthday to the United States Army Reserve. Currently more than 200,000 members strong, the US Army Reserve plays a vital role in our nation’s security. To all of your leadership, soldiers, civilian employees and family members, happy birthday!

During the Holocaust Week of Remembrance, we set aside time to remember not only those victims of the atrocities committed by Nazi Germany during WWII and the service men and women who gave their lives to end the horror, but also the devastating effect that intolerance can have when left unchecked. Part of honoring those lives lost is a vow to never allow that depth of hatred and persecution to exist anywhere in the world ever again. Our differences may be many, and our disagreements deep, but we must always work together despite this in order to succeed.

On this day in 1945, Nazi Germany’s unconditional surrender to Allied Forces in Berlin, Germany marked the end of World War II. Now known as Victory in Europe Day, or VE Day, this day has become not only a day to celebrate the victory over the Axis Powers in Europe but also to remember those brave men and women who sacrificed, both stateside and abroad, to make an Allied victory possible. The debt that we and the rest of the world owe you can never be repaid.

Ask any service member and they will tell you that when they volunteered to sacrifice for their country, they also volunteered the sacrifice of their family back home. Today is Military Spouse Appreciation Day, and we hope that those spouses and families of our service members know that we recognize and appreciate their sacrifices as much as we do their spouses in uniform.

Organizations like Children of Fallen Patriots Foundation work tirelessly to assist those children who have suffered the loss of a parent by funding their college education.

Today is Armed Forces Day, a day we set aside to recognize all who serve in our Armed Forces.  On behalf of myself and my entire staff, thank you to all of the men and women willing to serve this country and defend our freedoms!

On this day 73 years ago, over 5,000 ships, 11,000 aircraft, and 150,000 servicemen stormed the beaches of Normandy in what is the largest air, land, and sea operation ever executed. The courage and selflessness of those men cannot be overstated and should be equaled only by our debt to them.

Today, we celebrate two occasions that together form an integral part of the fabric of our country. It is both Flag Day and the 242nd birthday of the United States Army. Both have become American institutions that symbolize the freedoms we enjoy every day as American citizens.

Happy 78th birthday to the US Coast Guard Auxiliary. Your four cornerstones – vessel examination, education, operations, and fellowship – remain as relevant today as they did in 1941 when - 50,000 strong - you entered WWII and defended your nation.

In 2010, Congress designated today PTSD Awareness Day. In the years since, PTSD has continued to move to the forefront of issues with which our veterans and their families are dealing. Even with public awareness and effective treatments becoming more common, it is still our duty to help these servicemen and women adapt and overcome the effects of PTSD.

On this day 242 years ago, the Continental Congress authorized that one chaplain be attached to each regiment of the Continental Army.  Today, over 2,700 chaplains serve in the US Army, and they represent 140 different religions. Over 300 Army chaplains have died in combat, and 7 have been awarded the Medal of Honor. On the anniversary of their founding, we say thank you to those who serve our servicemembers.

Founded 227 years ago by then Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton as the Revenue Marine and responsible for enforcing the first tariff laws established by the US Congress, the United States Coast Guard is a crucial pillar of our armed services. To those who have served or are currently serving in the USCG, you truly have lived up to the motto of your branch: Semper Paratus (Always ready.)

Today, we recognize those servicemen and women who have received the oldest military award still awarded to US military members, the Purple Heart. Awarded to those who have been wounded or killed in action against an enemy of the United States, the Purple Heart is a symbol of the willingness of those brave men and women of our Armed Forces to answer the call of their country and stand between us and our enemies. Thank you to all who have borne the scars of battle.

On this day in 1820, Susan B. Anthony, one of our nation's most famous social reformers, was born. Anthony dedicated her life to the cause of women's suffrage and was also a prominent advocate for the abolition of slavery. 111 years after her death, we still remember her contributions to our country.
On Presidents' Day, we remember the service of all of those who held the highest office in our land and their commitment to their country.

I am greatly saddened to hear of the threats made against the Mandel Jewish Community Center in Beachwood this past Monday and I strongly condemn this hateful action against the Jewish community in Northeast Ohio. One of the foundational principles of our nation is the freedom of religion, a right so important and central to our identity that it is one of the first listed in our Constitution. The rising number of threats made against Jewish Community Centers is an affront to all Americans who cherish our right to practice any religion without fear or consequence. That is why I have joined over 150 of my colleagues in the House of Representatives in writing to the FBI, Department of Justice, and Department of Homeland Security to address the rising number of threats against Jewish Community Centers. I stand in solidarity with the members of the Jewish community and urge swift action to identify the source of these threats and to hold these individuals accountable to the full extent of the law.

I spoke about how trade policy effects Northeast Ohio because we are home to one of the largest dairy producing districts in the state. Ohio’s dairy sector relies significantly on exports. Today, some very unfair things are happening to our dairy farmers.  Canada’s protectionist policy is effectively blocking American dairy exports, by subsidizing Canadian milk proteins so that U.S. dairy farms are no longer competitive in trying to sell their product in Canada.  This is a concern not only to companies exporting to Canada but also to those exporting milk protein products around the world, since the Canadian pricing scheme is designed to undercut our sales on both fronts. I asked how we tackle this Canada dairy problem, and find a way forward to establish more open and dependable trading conditions. Spent a solid 12 hours debating the FY2018 budget in House Budget Committee GOP last night. Having spent over 30 years in the business world meeting payrolls and balancing budgets before coming to Congress, I have always maintained that Congress has a fundamental duty to pass responsible budgets and live within them—something that has happened far too rarely in Washington.   I applaud our Chair for putting forth a budget that actually balances over the next ten years and which includes policy proposals that will lead to badly needed economic growth in our nation.  This FY2018 budget also begins to address the greatest driver of our country’s growing debt by delivering real cuts to mandatory spending.  While I personally would have liked to include larger mandatory spending cuts, this budget is an important first step towards restoring responsibility and sustainability to America’s fiscal course.   And as member of the House Budget Committee, I’ve been honored to work along side my colleagues on the frontlines of this process as the Committee worked to craft an FY2018 budget blueprint.

For this week’s #WorkingWomenWednesday spotlight, it is my pleasure to recognize Cheryl Kirkbride. Kirkbride has been a private practice attorney for Kropf Wagner Law Firm in Orrville for 16 years, including being a partner for five of those years. She is also the Law Director of the City of Orrville for the past five years as well as the Solicitor for the Village of Smithville for the previous seven years. In addition to all the law work she does, she and her husband also own and assist in the operations of the The Inn at Walnut Creek in Holmes County Amish country for the past year. It is safe to say that she has a lot going on day to day, but she excels in everything, regardless of what is going on. Kirkbride shared with me her thoughts and insight based on her career experience in the law realm:   “The most challenging aspect of my career(s) is balance. My husband and I have 4 children, two of whom are still at home and the other two who haven’t been launched for too long. My job is extremely demanding – people tend to go to lawyers only after they have exhausted all other options and frequently tensions and emotions are high. Staying on top of client matters, communicating regularly, training younger lawyers and managing a heavy workload can be stressful. It is tough to keep all of the balls in the air and have something left for my family at the end of the day.   The most valuable thing I have learned from my job is to have empathy. People come to us in difficult times and everyone has a story. It sounds cliché, but as I have grown in my practice (and life), I have better understood the importance of taking time to listen to my clients’ concerns. I have also been able to share some of my family’s personal challenges with my clients – such as my father’s debilitating stroke and our long road following that event – to encourage and assist with resources of which they might not otherwise be aware.   My advice for young women would be that the Golden Rule never goes out of style. Treating people well, listening to their concerns, providing encouragement and support and becoming involved in your church, community, school , service clubs and non-profit organizations helps provide balance and rejuvenates your spirit.”  It is my honor to have Cheryl for this week’s #WorkingWomenWednesday.

On this day in 1901, we lost our 25th U.S. President, William McKinley.  Born January 29, 1843 in Niles, Ohio, he moved to Canton in 1867 and opened a small law office.  In 1869, he was elected prosecuting attorney of Stark County.  A few years later, he married Ida Saxton, of Canton.  Eventually, McKinley would be elected to Congress representing the 17th district of Ohio, which now does not exist.  It was redistricted at one point to our very own 16th district, but now most closely resembles the 13th district of Ohio.  Hailing from our local area, he would soon become Governor of Ohio in 1892, and then be elected President in 1896.  Unfortunately, McKinley would be shot on September 6th, six months into the second term of his presidency.  On September 14th, President McKinley would be pronounced dead. Today, I introduced a Resolution, H.RES. 530, offering 10 core principles on which our new tax code should be built.  As a CPA with 30 years of business experience, reforming our tax code has been my mission since arriving to Washington.  My hope is that these principles will help grow consensus and drive tax reform to the President’s desk.”   The Resolution affirms the commitment of the United States House of Representatives to simplify the tax code for all Americans.  Ten principles:  1. Make the tax code simple, fair, and easy to understand 2. Raise the standard deduction, increase child tax credits, and lower tax rates 3. Create cuts that touch all individuals and leverage higher rates of economic stimulus 4. Stop special interests from winning at the expense of the middle class 5. Make America the best place in the world to hire, invest, and grow 6. Support family business by eliminating the “Death Tax” 7. Retool the tax code to give American workers a level playing field with foreign competition 8. Switch to a territorial system that encourages companies to bring their profits back home 9. Encourage following regular order to ensure the greatest likelihood of success 10. Encourage all Americans to call on Congress and demand to put America first  You can read more and find full text here: http://bit.ly/2ytlITy  Here is the Resolution on its way to the Cloakroom:

For this week’s #WorkingWomenWednesday, it is my pleasure to honor Leslie Edwards, the Technical/Production Manager with Survitec Group, a company that specializes in safety survival solutions.  Before becoming a technical/production manager, Leslie previously served as an Industrial Engineer and a Continuous Improvement Manager.  Her experience has been predominately in manufacturing, but industrial engineering covers a very broad spectrum for opportunities to also work in health care, banking, and numerous other industries.Leslie shared her experiences with me as well as advice for other future female leaders.  On the most valuable thing learned from her job:  “When working with different levels of employees ranging from the production staff to the senior management and board members, it is important to have the ability to communicate with people at every level.  You have to learn to communicate effectively and that might be different depending on your audience.  Always know your subject matter when presenting information.  If you don’t know something, don’t pretend that you do.  If you don’t have the answer, then let them know that you don’t know but you will find out and follow up.  Always follow up!”  On advice for young future female leaders:  “Always treat people with respect regardless of their level of authority or influence. Everyone has something to contribute, so it is important to listen.  The best ideas don’t always come from the ‘experts’. Be professional and be true to your word.  You never know who is watching!  Be passionate about what you do.  I am fortunate to work for a company that designs and manufactures survival equipment and we are a supplier for the United States Department of Defense.  I am proud to know that my efforts are in some small way keeping our soldiers safe to allow them to protect our rights and freedom.”  Thank you, Leslie, for being this week’s #WorkingWomenWednesday spotlight.

I applaud the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act that we passed in the House last night. This new legislation would prohibit abortions after the 20th week of pregnancy, with exceptions for rape, incest, and danger to the mother’s life. New evidence confirms what we already knew – by 20 weeks, an unborn child can already feel the pain of an abortion.  I firmly believe that life is a precious gift and that we must protect the sanctity of life, from the moment of conception on. As a member of the House Pro-Life Caucus, I am proud to serve as a strong and active advocate for the cause of protecting life and enacting legislation to preserve the rights of the unborn.

Renacci Pushes to Preserve the Doctor-Patient Relationship by Creating Access to Rehabilitation for Every Senior

Today, under current Medicare payment policy, even if a doctor knows the proper care setting for a patient is at a Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF), the patient must have an inpatient hospital stay lasting at least 3 days in order for Medicare to cover the costs.   In order to protect beneficiary access to rehabilitation services, I reintroduced the Creating Access to Rehabilitation for Every Senior (CARES) Act, which waives the 3-day inpatient stay requirement for SNFs that meet certain quality measures. If you really think about it, it’s ridiculous to think that this policy stood for so long in the first place. These patients are the frailest and oldest of the Medicare population. The three-day requirement is arbitrary as it holds no clinical basis. Not only that, but patients who need the services of a SNF most, are in essence forced to first meet the unnecessary hospital stay requirement.   Read more in my press release here: http://bit.ly/2Bus6ze
